summary:
Moves a save directory from it's default location to another drive, leaving a symlink in its wake.
Helps to free up space on your C: drive by allowing games to keep saves on other drives, even if it's not normally supported.
descriptionHtml:
SaveMover Copyright (C) 2014 Skwerlman

All bugs and suggestions should go [url=https://github.com/skwerlman/SaveMover/issues]here[/url].

If you're having any issues with the files, spot any typos, or encounter a bug, please let me know.
If you're good with batch, feel free to take a look at my [url=https://github.com/skwerlman/SaveMover/blob/master/src/savemover.bat]source code[/url] and leave any suggestions/questions/issues you might have.
The is the first public-release application I've written, so if you have any feedback at all, please let me know!

This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or
(at your option) any later version.

This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the
GNU General Public License for more details.

You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
along with this program. If not, see [url=http://www.gnu.org/licenses/]http://www.gnu.org/licenses/[/url]

Intro
Let's say you have a 128GB SSD. You put your OS there, and put your games on another drive, because they're big, and you don't want to fill your OS drive. But, alas! The games you moved to the other drive are storing all their save data on your OS drive, and you're almost out of room! Sure, some games support changing their save location, but in many cases, like Skyrim for example, it's hard and doesn't always work. That very problem inspired me to find a solution to the issue, and automate it. And here it is!

Requirements
* Windows newer than Windows 95 (but, seriously, whose isn't?)
* 2 or more hard drives
* At least 80 KB of disk space for this program
* 3 MB RAM
* ROBOCOPY.EXE (Included in basically every copy of Windows since 2003)

Instructions
**THIS IS STILL IN ALPHA! BACK UP YOUR SAVES BEFORE RUNNING THIS!**

1. Download either savemover_32.exe or savemover_64.exe, depending on your OS version (32- or 64-bit).
2. Run savemover as an administrator.
3. When prompted, enter the letter of the drive where you'd like to move the save files, then press enter. [i](If you wanted to move them to your S: drive, you'd enter S)[/i]
4. When prompted, enter the name of the save folder to move, then press enter. [i](For C:/Users/name/Documents/My Games/Skyrim/, you'd enter Skyrim)[/i]
5. After confirming that you entered the correct info, press enter again.
6. That's it!

Your saves will be located at DRIVELETTER:Savegames
author: Skwerlman

files.name: SaveMover-32bit
files.changelogHtml:
Added support for commandline args
Cleaned up output
Added help option (use 'savemover help' without quotes)
Fixed a typo in the startup message
